Description: Document the foundational business philosophy distilled from 20 years of experience. This is the 'why' behind every process and tool. Covers principles of efficiency; decision-making frameworks; anti-patterns to avoid; and the mental models that drive consistently good outcomes. This epic produces the intellectual foundation that all other epics build on.

A concise (10-20 page) document laying out the fundamental beliefs about how businesses should operate. Not generic MBA platitudes — specific; opinionated; battle-tested principles. Examples: 'Automate the second time; not the first'; 'Documentation is a product; not a chore'; 'Every process should have an owner and an expiration date'.

A structured approach to making business and technical decisions efficiently. Covers: when to decide fast vs deliberate; how to evaluate trade-offs; reversible vs irreversible decisions; the cost of delayed decisions. Include decision templates and real examples.

Summary: Catalog common anti-patterns and failure modes
Description: Document the recurring mistakes you've seen across 20 years: premature optimization of processes; meeting culture replacing action; documentation debt; over-engineering; under-communicating; hero culture; etc. For each anti-pattern: description; how to recognize it; how to fix it; real-world example.

Summary: Write the build vs buy vs borrow framework
Description: When should a company build custom tools vs buy off-the-shelf vs adapt open source? A decision framework based on: strategic differentiation; maintenance burden; switching costs; team capability; time horizon. Include scoring rubric.

The philosophy of matching effort to impact: not every problem needs a big solution. When a spreadsheet beats a database. When a script beats a platform. When a conversation beats a document. The art of knowing when 'good enough' is the right answer.

Document and tool-ify the methodology for going from idea to working prototype fast. Drawn from the POE2 overlay experience (0 to production in 12 sessions using AI-augmented development) and years of similar rapid builds. Covers ideation; scoping; iterative build; and launch patterns.

How to go from 'I have an idea' to 'it works and people are using it' in days not months. The session-based development approach (as demonstrated by the POE2 overlay). Covers: scoping to MVP; session planning; progress tracking; when to polish vs when to ship; how to avoid scope creep.

A reusable template/checklist for starting any new project: problem statement; success criteria; MVP scope; tech stack decision; first 3 milestones; known risks; who needs to know. Should be completable in 30 minutes — if it takes longer the project isn't well-scoped.

A lightweight template for planning each development session (2-4 hours of focused work). Includes: goals for this session; blockers from last session; priority-ordered task list; definition of done. Inspired by the POE2 overlay session logs in TODO.md.

How to ship incrementally: what to include in v0.1 vs v0.5 vs v1.0. The art of slicing features into shippable increments. When to cut corners (prototype) vs when to invest in quality (foundation). Real examples from projects.

Summary: Build a scope control decision tree
Description: A visual decision tree for 'should we add this feature now?'. Inputs: does it block launch?; how many users want it?; how hard is it?; does it compound?. Outputs: do it now; add to backlog; reject; defer to v2. Printable one-pager.

Document how to use AI tools (Claude; GPT; Copilot; etc.) effectively for software development and business operations. Not 'AI is magic' hype — practical; honest guidance on where AI helps; where it hurts; and how to build AI-augmented workflows that actually work. Based on extensive hands-on experience with Claude Code.

Comprehensive guide to using AI coding assistants effectively. Covers: when to use AI vs code manually; how to write effective prompts; how to review AI-generated code; common failure modes; context management; the handoff document pattern (like CLAUDE_CODE_HANDOFF.md); and maintaining code quality with AI assistance.

How to maintain project context across AI sessions. The MEMORY.md pattern; the handoff document pattern; the TODO.md as living state. How to structure information so AI assistants can be productive immediately. What to persist vs what to regenerate.

Summary: Build the AI prompt template library
Description: A collection of proven prompt templates for common development tasks: debugging; refactoring; code review; architecture design; test writing; documentation; etc. Each template includes: the prompt; when to use it; expected output quality; common pitfalls.

Summary: Document AI tool selection and evaluation
Description: Framework for evaluating AI tools: Claude Code vs Cursor vs Copilot vs ChatGPT vs others. Strengths/weaknesses of each. When to use which tool for which task. Cost/benefit analysis. How to avoid vendor lock-in. Updated evaluation criteria as tools evolve rapidly.

Summary: Write the AI quality assurance guide
Description: How to maintain code quality when AI is writing significant portions of the code. Review patterns; testing strategies; architectural guardrails; CLAUDE.md/rules files as constraints; when AI output needs human review vs when it can be trusted. The 'trust but verify' framework.

How to run multiple AI agents on a project simultaneously (as the user does with multiple Claude instances). Task decomposition; avoiding conflicts; merge strategies; when parallel agents help vs when they create chaos. The orchestration layer.

Document and build tools for designing; implementing; and automating business processes. The methodology for looking at any workflow and making it more efficient — not just with AI but with smart process design; appropriate automation; and continuous improvement.

A step-by-step guide for auditing any business process: how to map the current state; identify bottlenecks; measure waste; classify steps (value-add vs necessary waste vs pure waste); and propose improvements. Include interview templates and observation guides.

Summary: Build the process mapping template toolkit
Description: Templates and tools for documenting processes: flowchart templates; RACI matrices; swim-lane diagram generators; time-motion analysis sheets. Should be usable in common tools (Excel; Miro; Lucidchart) not locked into proprietary software.

When to automate a process vs when to leave it manual. Factors: frequency; error rate; cost of errors; human judgment required; maintenance burden of automation; team capability. The ROI calculation template. Common automation traps (automating broken processes makes them faster but not better).

Summary: Build a workflow automation starter kit
Description: Ready-to-customize automation templates for common business workflows: onboarding checklists; code review processes; release management; incident response; customer feedback loops. Built on accessible tools (GitHub Actions; Zapier; Power Automate; or simple scripts).

How to build a culture of continuous process improvement without it becoming bureaucratic. Lightweight retrospective formats; improvement backlogs; metrics that matter; the kaizen mindset adapted for tech teams. How to make improvement a habit not an initiative.

Document the methodology for capturing; organizing; and distributing institutional knowledge. How to prevent knowledge loss; reduce onboarding time; and build a culture where documentation is a first-class product. Includes the tooling patterns (handoff docs; memory files; living docs).

Comprehensive guide to organizational knowledge management. Covers: what to document vs what to leave tribal; documentation formats for different purposes (reference; tutorial; decision record; runbook); ownership and maintenance; the documentation lifecycle.

Formalize the pattern demonstrated by CLAUDE_CODE_HANDOFF.md: a living document that captures everything a new person (or AI) needs to be productive on a project. Template; examples; anti-patterns (too long; too vague; outdated). Works for human-to-human; human-to-AI; and team-to-team handoffs.

Architecture Decision Record (ADR) template adapted for business decisions too. Sections: context; decision; consequences; alternatives considered; who decided; when to revisit. Lightweight enough to actually get used. Include a searchable index pattern.

How to keep documentation alive and accurate instead of rotting. Patterns: docs-as-code; automated staleness detection; ownership rotation; documentation sprints; CI for docs (broken link checks; freshness alerts). The MEMORY.md auto-update pattern as an example.

A template for creating a new-hire onboarding guide for any team/project. Sections: architecture overview; key contacts; local dev setup; common tasks with walkthroughs; glossary; FAQ. Goal: new team member productive in days not weeks.
Frameworks for team communication; meeting efficiency; async-first culture; and reducing coordination overhead. Based on 20 years of observing what makes teams fast vs what makes them slow.

Rules for meetings that don't waste time: when a meeting is justified vs when async works; required meeting structure (agenda; timekeeper; decisions documented); the 'no spectator' rule; recurring meeting audit pattern. Include the 'meeting cost calculator' concept.

How to build a team culture that defaults to async communication. When to use which channel (Slack; email; doc comment; PR review; meeting). How to write async messages that don't generate follow-up questions. The 'write it once; share it forever' principle.

When and how to escalate issues without creating drama. The escalation ladder: self-serve → peer → lead → manager. What information to include when escalating. How managers should handle escalations. Anti-pattern: everything is urgent.

Summary: Build the team health check template
Description: A quarterly team health assessment: velocity trends; communication patterns; technical debt levels; team satisfaction; knowledge distribution (bus factor). Lightweight survey + metrics dashboard. Identifies problems before they become crises.

Specific practices for distributed teams: timezone-aware scheduling; async standup formats; virtual collaboration tools; building trust without hallway conversations; managing the 'out of sight out of mind' problem.
Package the methodology and tools for external consumption. Covers: book/e-book formatting; workshop design; consulting engagement structure; pricing; sales materials; and the platform for delivery.

Summary: Design the playbook format and structure
Description: Decide on the final format: e-book (PDF/epub); web-based (Gitbook/Notion); printed book; or interactive course. Design the information architecture: how chapters flow; how tools reference principles; how examples connect to frameworks. Consider multiple formats from the same source content.

A structured template for consulting engagements where you bring this methodology to a company. Phases: assessment (1-2 weeks); recommendations (1 week); implementation coaching (4-12 weeks); retrospective (1 week). Deliverables; pricing model; success criteria per phase.

Design a 1-day or 2-day workshop that teaches the core methodology to a team. Modules: philosophy (1h); process audit exercise (2h); AI-augmented workflow lab (2h); knowledge management setup (1h); action planning (1h). Include facilitator guide and participant materials.

A public-facing website that presents the methodology: overview; framework summaries; sample chapters; tool downloads; testimonials; consulting inquiry form. Could be a simple static site (GitHub Pages) or a more polished marketing site.

Template for writing case studies that demonstrate the methodology in action. The POE2 overlay project is case study #1: from idea to working product in 12 sessions using AI-augmented development; rapid prototyping; and session-based iteration. Include metrics and outcomes.

Summary: Design the pricing and licensing model
Description: Define how the playbook and tools are licensed: open-source playbook + paid consulting?; freemium (core free; advanced tools paid)?; book sales + workshop fees?; subscription model?. Research what similar methodology products charge. Balance accessibility with sustainability.
Build the technical platform for hosting; distributing; and maintaining the methodology content and tools. Covers content management; template distribution; analytics; and feedback collection.

Choose and set up the content authoring system: Markdown source files → multiple output formats (web; PDF; epub). Could use mdBook; Docusaurus; Pandoc; or a custom pipeline. Version-controlled in Git so methodology evolves with the same rigor as code.

A way for users to download and use the toolkit templates: GitHub repo with cookiecutter/copier templates; downloadable ZIP from the website; or npm/pip package with a CLI ('init-project'; 'init-process-audit'). Templates should be customizable.

Track how the methodology is being adopted: which chapters are most read; which tools are most downloaded; which templates are most used; feedback ratings. Aggregate anonymized data to guide updates and identify gaps. Respect privacy.

Allow users to suggest improvements; submit their own templates/patterns; and share case studies. Could be as simple as GitHub Issues/Discussions or a more structured community platform. The methodology should evolve with real-world input.
